awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: 2016-2019 Development of the Askaryan Radio Array Ultra-High Energy Neutrino Detector at the South Pole
awd_abstract_narration:
Ultra-high-energy neutrinos are unique astrophysical messengers that interact weakly with intervening matter and can therefore be used to probe the distant universe.  A small but theoretically observable flux of these ultra-high-energy neutrinos is expected to be produced by the interaction between high-energy "cosmic ray" charged particles and cosmic microwave background photons as the cosmic rays travel through the Universe. Observing these cosmogenic neutrinos would allow physicists to begin to study physics at energies beyond the standard models. The large volume of radio transparent ice covering the geographic South Pole in Antarctica has hosted several pioneering efforts to detect these high energies neutrinos using a radio Cherenkov "Askaryan effect."  The Askaryan effect describes the process by which ultra-high-energy neutrinos traversing the dense polar ice generate observable radio waves.  The Askaryan Radio Array (ARA), located at the South Pole Station, was designed to exploit this phenomenon to first detect and ultimately study these ultra-high-energy neutrinos.  This award provides funding to deploy two more ARA stations to the existing suite of three stations, and to continue observations.  The award will support the involvement of students, including undergraduate students, who will be engaged in on-site activities at the South Pole.  It will also support outreach efforts including activities with QuarkNet.

ARA is designed to be implemented in phases.  During the initial phase the ARA project deployed a testbed and three full stations that used equipment designed and built for the co-located IceCube Neutrino Observatory.  With this award the project will deploy two more stations and continue observations with all stations to demonstrate the technology, accumulate knowledge about radio frequency properties of the upper layers of the ice sheet at South Pole, and develop reliable hardware and software for deployable in-ice stations in the future.

por.por_cntn:
This project is a three year interval in an international effort to detect Ultra-High-Energy (UHE) astrophysical neutrinos. This effort began with prototype developments in 2011 and should culminate in the deployment, operation, and exploitation of a detector to observe and characterize these high energy particles. The detector is named the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA), after Gurgen Askaryan who first suggested the physical principles behind the detector design. The ARA collaboration includes seven domestic and four foreign institutions. The University of Wisconsin is the lead institution.

Background: For over a century, observations have documented a flux of relativistic cosmic rays with an energy spectrum that extends up to 100 billion (100*B) times the rest mass energy of a proton. The energy for these particles is thought to be gravitational energy released in the formation of neutron stars and black holes; however, there is no direct cosmic ray evidence to support this hypothesis since the charged nuclei do not travel in straight lines while passing through galactic and cosmic magnetic fields. To resolve this, scientists operate within the evolving field of multi-messenger astrophysics. The high energy cosmic ray nuclei are expected to collide with matter or photons of light, generating neutral particles (gamma-rays and neutrinos) that point back to the sources.

UHE gamma-rays are absorbed while propagating on cosmological length/time scales, and so their observation is limited to lower energies. In contrast, neutrinos are not absorbed either in the source or in propagation, and are ideal messengers pointing to sources of UHE particles. Since they interact weakly with matter, a detector with a large area/volume is required just to capture a few. The IceCube neutrino observatory was built as a 1 cubic km detector to address this opportunity, and indeed IceCube has confirmed a diffuse flux of astrophysical neutrinos with energies up to 10 million proton mass (10*M). It is an open question if the sources of these 10*M neutrinos would be the same as the sources of 10*B cosmic rays, but to study this requires a detector much larger than IceCube.

When high energy neutrinos interact with matter they create cascades of charged particles, which in turn are sources of electromagnetic energy. IceCube observes that energy as optical photons, which travel ~100m through the glacial ice. ARA observes radio energy from those cascades at 100-1000 MHz. These radio waves pass through cold polar ice with an attenuation length of order one kilometer. The design of ARA is to deploy multiple "stations" ~200m deep in the glacial ice at South Pole. Each station consists of an array of 16 antennas to detect the radiation, and record an event which can later be analyzed to reconstruct the cascade and infer the neutrino which produced it. The cost of a station is less than $100,000, and each station has an effective volume comparable to IceCube, but with a higher energy threshold. The eventual goal is to build an array with 1000 times the volume of IceCube for a fraction of the cost.

The scope of three original ARA stations was confined to the highest energies 1-100*B, with the expectation that the UHE cosmic rays were mostly protons which would produce "cosmogenic" neutrinos as they pass through the cosmic background radiation. The current project has added two more stations, and operated all 5 for 1.5 yrs as of this report. Analysis of the new data will take place subsequent to this report. One of the new stations includes a prototype low thresold trigger enabling neutrino detection at an energy 0.1*B (100*M). The low threshold is achieved by coherently adding the signals from a string of 8 similar antennas. This technique is extendable down to 30*M, and in a larger array will overlap/complement energies probed by a second generation IceCube.

To summarize: the major outcomes of the 2016-2019 interval of the ARA project are
a) construction and deployment of two additional ARA stations
b) operation of an array of five such stations, and
c) design, construction, and deployment of a low threshold trigger

At the University of Delaware, Senior Technician James Roth helped develop control systems for the ARA drill, and was drill lead for the 2017-18 deployment season. Graduate student Yue Pan extended the ARA data management and monitoring operations to handle five stations, and is currently co-organizer of the operations and monitoring effort. He was a member of the 2018-19 on-ice field team. He has also contributed to improvements in the ARA simulation package. In addition to overseeing the Delaware effort, local PI David Seckel played an important role in identifying impulsive signals from a deep radio pulser buried within IceCube, demostrating our ability to reconstruct neutrino interaction verticies in the ice at distances of several km from an ARA station.
